civ.name: Aztecs
civ.notes: Aztecs have very strong Eagle Warriors with their unique technology Garland Wars giving all their infantry +4 attack. Eagle Warriors are fast raiding units that excel against ranged and siege units, however they fall flat against other melee units. That's where your Jaguar Warriors (anti-infantry) and Pikemen (anti-cavalry) come in.

civ.name: Berbers
civ.notes: Berbers have cheaper cavalry, so you should use this to your advantage. An army of Cavaliers and Camels backed up by Skirmishers - to take care of those pesky Halberdiers - can go a long way.

civ.name: Britons
civ.notes: The Britons' claim to fame are their long-range archers, including their unique unit Longbowman and their Arbalests from the Archery Range. Light Cavalry to take care of enemy Skirmishers and Siege Units, and Halberdiers to take care of enemy Cavaliers/Paladins, which are the biggest counters to archers. Rain on 'em with your Longbowmen!

civ.name: Burmese
civ.notes: The Burmese has very good Battle Elephants. Their unique unitm, the Arambai, is very inaccurate at long range, so you have to put them very close (2 tiles away max) to the enemy to do damage. Since both the Arambai and the Battle Elephants are cavalry, the opposing civs will build Halberdiers and Camels to counter you. To kill Halberdiers, Skirmishers will do the trick. For Camels, your Halberdiers can take care of them.

civ.name: Byzantines
civ.primary: Arbalests (Archery Range) or Cataphracts (Castle) or Paladins (Barracks)
civ.notes: The Byzantines are kings of "trash" units, i.e. units that do not cost gold. These units are the Skirmishers, the Halberdiers, and the Hussar. Trash units for Byzantines cost less resources than other civs, except for Hussars. However, that means you should spend gold on more powerful units. The Byzantines unfortunately lack the final Melee Offensive upgrade at the Blacksmith (Blast Furnace), so their melee units deal less damage than other civs. The exception is their unique unit, the Cataphracts. The Cataphracts deal area of effect damage once the Imperial tech Logistica is researched at the Castle, meaning for every attack they will do an extra 5 damage to any nearby units. Cataphracts also deal bonus damage to infantry. The Byzantines also get fully upgraded Arbalests, so their Archery range units are strong. Combined either Arbalests and Cataphracts with their cheaper trash units as supporting units and the Byzantines can have a formidable military force.

civ.name: Celts
civ.notes: The Celts excel in Siege Workshop units, particularly the Scorpions and the Onagers. Onagers can do friendly fire damage though, thus they are a bit harder to use than Scorpions. Siege Workshops shred through archers and skirmishers, but they struggle against melee and other siege units. To take care of that, the Halberdiers can deal with any cavalry trying to get to your siege units, while the Woad Raiders can take care of opposing siege units.

civ.name: Chinese
civ.primary: Chu Ko Nu (Castle) or Scorpions (Siege Workshop)
civ.notes: The Chinese have very good unique units in the Chu Ko Nu. They have less range than other archers, but they do significantly more damage, even to high pierce armor targets such as Rams. However, siege units such as Onagers will still pose a threat to the low melee armored Chu Ko Nus. To kill siege units, go for Light Cavalry. To kill any cavalry that's trying to get to your archers, go for Halberdiers and Camels.

civ.name: Ethiopians
civ.notes: Ethiopians have faster firing archers, thus you can use this advantage by making lots of archers. They also have very strong Siege units with their Imperial unique tech, Torsion Engine. You should have Hussars in front of your archers and siege units as a meat shield, while having Halberdiers to deal with any incoming Cavalry. Shotel Warriors get created very quickly, thus they can be used to defend against opposing Rams, Skirmishers, and Halberdiers.

civ.name: Franks
civ.notes: The Franks have one good unit, and that is the Paladin. Granted, they have the best Paladins in the game, so that should be something. They also get free Mill farm upgrades, so their Farms are very good (not as good as Slavs though). Paladins' biggest counters are Halberdiers and Camels. To take care of Halberdiers, go for Skirmishers. Your own Halberdiers take care of opposing Camels. However, your Skirmishers lack the final archer upgrades in the Blacksmith, so they are not too strong. To combat this, if you have any extra gold, consider building Throwing Axemen to counter the Halberdiers.

civ.name: Goths
civ.primary: Huskarls (Castles and Barracks once Anarchy is researched)
civ.notes: The Goths have the best infantry in the game because their infantry is cheaper and their Barracks work faster, especially after their Imperial tech Perfusion is researched. The Huskarls, their unique unit, can be created from the Goths' Barracks after their Castle Age tech Anarchy is researched. The Huskarls have very high pierce armor, making them excellent against archers and Scorpions. Huskarls are weak against cavalry and onagers. Halberdiers can handle cavalry, while the Hussars can handle onagers.

civ.name: Huns
civ.notes: The Huns are a very aggressive civ, simply because they do not have to waste early resources on building houses. They have a great Stable, with their Stables working 20% faster. They also have cheaper Cavalry Archers if you opt to use them as the backbone of your military. If you opt to go for Paladins, go for Skirmishers to kill off the pesky Halberdiers. If you want to build Cavalry Archers, build some Hussars to take care of skirmishers and siege. If you see opposing Camels, start making Halberdiers.

civ.name: Incas
civ.notes: Similar to the Aztes, the Incas are a Meso civ with strong infantry units. Their unique unit, the Kamayuk, is anti-cavalry, so if you build them you don't have to build any additional Halberdiers. Kamayuks are weak against opposing infantry and archers, so consider building Arbalests to kill infantry and Skirmishers to kill archers.

civ.name: Indians
civ.support: Skirmishers (Archery Range), Hand Cannoneer (Archery Range after Chemistry is researched at the University)
civ.notes: The Indians have one of the best camels in the game, them being the Imperial Camels. Camels are anti-cavalry, and Indian Camels are especially tanky thanks to their +1 Melee/ +1 Pierce armor. Camels are weak against Archers and Halberdiers, both units that Skirmishers can counter. In the late game, Hand Cannoneer can also be used against Halberdiers since Hand Cannoneers get +10 attack against infantry.

civ.name: Italians
civ.notes: The Italians have a great unique unit in the Genoese Crossbowman since these archers are anti-cavalry, thus they innately counter one of the archers' weakness. However, they are still weak to Skirmishers and Siege units, where you can use the Hussars to counter.

civ.name: Japanese
civ.support: Light Cavalry (Stables), Halberdiers (Barracks), Skirmishers (Archery Range), Scorpions (Siege Workshop)
civ.notes: The Japanese have very great infantry (infantry attacks faster) and a complete Archery Range. They also have a complete Blacksmith tree, so any units they go for can be fully upgraded at the Blacksmith. Furthermore, they also have a complete Barracks, save for the Meso-only Eagle Warriors. Thus, you can either go for an army of mass Arbalests combined with Halberdiers and Light Cav, or you can go for Samurai (anti-unique unit), Halberdiers and Skirmishers, depending on the opposing army composition. If you have spare gold in the end game, Heavy Scorpions are also a good choice to counter opposing Archers. Lastly, the Japanes Trebuchets packs and unpacks faster, thus you can destroy a castle, pack your Trebuchet, and move it to destroy the next building much faster than any other civ.

civ.name: Khmer
civ.notes: Khmer has strong Battle Elephants and strong Scorpions after their Imperial tech Double Crossbow is researched. However, both units are gold-intensive, so you should pick only one of the two units to mass. Battle Elephants are very weak to Halberdiers and Monks, thus you'll need Skirmishers for Halberdiers and Light Cavalry for Monks. If you decide to mass Scorpions, go for Halberdiers to stop the opposing cavalry units.

civ.name: Koreans
civ.notes: Koreans have very strong towers and they have a bonus to stone mining, so consider building lots of Towers and Castles for defensive or offensive purposes (tower rushes come to mind). Koreans also have a good Archery Range and a great unique unit in the tanky War Wagons. War Wagons are considered Cavalry Archers and they are fairly slow, so opposing cavalry can counter them, especially Camels. To counter this, make Halberdiers to kill opposing cavalry. Also, make Hussars to counter any opposing Skirmishers that try to kill your War Wagons.

civ.name: Magyars
civ.support: Skirmishers (Archery Range), Halberdiers (Barrracks), Hussars (Stables), Magyar Hussars (Castle)
civ.notes: The Magyars have great cavalry as well as great cavalry archers. If you decide to mass Paladins, make Skirmishers to kill opposing Halberdiers and Halberdiers to kill opposing Camels. If you feel more like Cavalry Archers, go for Hussars to kill the Skirmishers and your unique unit Magyar Hussars to kill Siege. Note that if you want to make Magyar Hussars, consider researching the Castle age tech Mercenaries at the Castle so that your Magyar Hussars cost no gold.

civ.name: Malay
civ.notes: Although Malay has access to the Battle Elephant, they do not have access to the 2 final Blacksmith cavalry armor upgrades, thus making their cavalry line very very weak. Thus, you should focus on their fully upgraded Arbalests as well as their Two-Handed Swordsman, which costs no gold after the Imperial tech Forced Levy is researched. The Two-Handed Swordsman serve as the Malay's Skirmishers and Halberdiers counters since their Light Cavalry is weak, and since they cost no gold after Forced Levy is researched, the Two-Handed Swordsman is considered a "trash" unit. Their Skirmishers can also be used to counter opposing Skirmishers, although this is not as effective as the Two-Handed Swordsman.

civ.name: Malians
civ.notes: The Malians have strong Stable units due to their Imperial tech Farimba, giving all their cavalry +5 attack. They unfortunately do not have Paladins, so Heavy Camels are their best units. If the enemy is not building cavalry, you can also consider going Cavaliers. As usual, cavalry can be countered with Halberdiers, so Skirmishers should be made to kill the Halberdiers. Since Malian infantry get extra pierce armor per age as well, Pikeman can also be a good units in case you need to counter opposing siege/archers. The Malians team bonus has their team research at the university 80% faster, thus they can upgrade their towers all the way to keep. If you want to build towers, remember to upgrade them at the University.

civ.name: Mayans
civ.support: Halberdiers (Barracks), Skirmishers (Archery Range), Rams (Siege Workshop), Eagle Warriors (Barracks)
civ.notes: The Mayans have the one of the best unique unit in the game, Plumed Archers, and their cost is also reduced in by 10%/20%/30% per age starting from Feudal Age. As usual, make Halberdiers to counter opposing cavalry, and Skirmishers to counter opposing Skirmishers. While Plumed Archers do have a fair bit of pierce armor, they still do not fight Skirmishers very well. Since the Mayans do not have access to any cavalry, you'll have to do with your own Skirmishers as a cost-effective way to counter opposing Skirmishers. When you have an excess amount of gold, consider making some Eagles as well. Mayans are VERY weak to opposing siege (Plumed needs to be micro excessively in order to avoid death), and Eagles can greatly help with that weakness.

civ.name: Mongols
civ.notes: Similar to the Mayans, the Mongols have great archer units in the Mangudai. The Mongols also have Hussars with extra HP, thus they have an effective ounter against opposing skirmishers. For any opposing camels or paladins, consider making some Pikeman if your Mangudai cannot fight back. From what I've seen from pro play though, the Mangudai can usually tear through Paladins given that there are enough number of Mangudais available.

civ.name: Persians
civ.notes: Similar to the Huns, the Persians have great cavalry. Dissimilar to the Huns, the Persians' Archery Range are only decent since they lack Bracer, the last ranged units attack/range upgrade at the Blacksmith. Thus, it can be difficult for Persians to counter opposing Halberdiers with Skirmishers. Your cavalry is great though, so sheer number of paladins might overpower the Halberdiers. To counter opposing camels, build your fully upgraded Halberdiers.

civ.name: Portuguese
civ.notes: The Portuguese have good siege units thanks to their Imperial tech Arquebus, which essentially gives Ballistic to your siege units. In other words, their siege units will hit moving targets more accurately. You should also build Halberdiers to counter opposing Cavalry, and Light Cav to counter opposing mangonels.

civ.name: Saracens
civ.primary: Heavy Camels (Stables) or Arbalests (Archery Range) or Cavalry Archers (Archery Range)
civ.notes: The Saracens have a very open tech tree, which means that they can build many types of units. They do specialize in Camels, so that is a good choice to go for. Their Mamelukes are great units, however they are very costly (costs more gold than a Paladin), thus the Mamelukes are hard to mass. To counter opposing Halberdiers, build your own fully upgraded Skirmishers. To counter opposing Siege, you can build fully upgraded Hussars. Also, use your market excessively, as you can sell resources more efficiently than other civs, AND your market costs less wood as well, which can help your fast castle/slinging if that is the strategy you are going for.
